description:
Human papillomavirus (HPV) 167 is a member of the Papillomaviridae family, which is a group of small, non-enveloped DNA viruses that infect the epithelial cells of various host species, including humans. HPV-167 is a high-risk genotype of HPV that is primarily associated with the development of cervical cancer and other anogenital cancers in humans.

The viral genome of HPV-167 consists of a circular, double-stranded DNA molecule that encodes for several essential viral proteins, including the E6 and E7 oncoproteins, which are known to disrupt the normal cell cycle and promote cellular transformation. The virus primarily targets the basal cells of the squamous epithelium, where it can establish a persistent infection and potentially lead to the development of precancerous lesions and invasive carcinomas.

HPV-167 is transmitted through sexual contact and can be detected in the genital tract, including the cervix, vulva, and penis. It is considered a high-risk genotype due to its increased potential for causing cervical cancer and other associated malignancies, compared to lower-risk HPV types.

Early detection and screening for HPV-167 infection, as well as the administration of HPV vaccines, are crucial public health measures to reduce the incidence and burden of HPV-related diseases.
